title: Energy conservation - -2 nC 1 mg and 10 nC spheres

content.question: Two small spheres are being studied in a lab. The spheres are inside a chamber where the air has been removed. One sphere is fixed in place and has a charge of <math alttext="positive 10 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math>, while the other sphere has a charge of <math alttext="negative 2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math> and is released from rest at a long distance from the fixed sphere. Gravitational forces acting on the spheres are negligible. If the <math alttext="negative 2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math> sphere has a mass of <math alttext="1 times 10 to the negative 6 power kilogram" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></mpadded></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>kg</mi></math>, which of the following is most nearly the speed of the <math alttext="negative 2 nanocoulombs" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>nC</mi></math> sphere when the spheres’ centers are <math alttext="6 millimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>6</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>mm</mi></math> are apart?

choices.label: <math alttext="3 times 10 to the negative 5 power meter per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn></mpadded></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>
<math alttext="8 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>
<math alttext="100 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>

<math alttext="2 times 10 to the fifth power meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mo>×</mo><msup><mn>10</mn><mpadded><mn>5</mn></mpadded></msup><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="8 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>8</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math>
